---
title: Stacked Bar Graphs
---

Here is the example from [PassRates.html](PassRates.html) showing how to make a stack bar graph showing the column proportions for a two-way table.

```{r}
results <- matrix(c(60, 23, 29, 11), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)
colnames(results) = c("Male", "Female")
rownames(results) = c("Pass", "Failed")
results
barplot(prop.table(results, margin = 2), col = cm.colors(2), ylab = "Proportion", legend = T)
```

Here is a ggplots version of the same graph.

```{r}
library("ggplot2")
df_counts <- as.data.frame(as.table(results))
colnames(df_counts) <- c("Group", "Category", "Count")

ggplot(df_counts, aes(x = Category, y = Count, fill = Group)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "fill") +
  ylab("Proportion") +
  theme_minimal()
```
